title: 114_hr5480
content: The "Boosting Equity for the American Middle Class Act of 2016" or the "BEAM Act of 2016" introduces a refundable credit for early principal payments on certain home mortgages under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "BEAM Act of 2016" introduces a credit for excess home mortgage principal payments made by individuals, limited to 50% of the payments and capped at $500 annually. There is also a lifetime limitation and a reduction based on modified adjusted gross income. The credit for excess home mortgage principal payments is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, with a minimum reduction of zero. Modified adjusted gross income includes adjusted gross income plus any excluded amounts under specific sections. The credit for excess home mortgage principal payments is based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, with a minimum reduction of zero. Excess home mortgage principal payments refer to the amount of principal paid by the taxpayer exceeding the amount that would have been paid if all required payments were made on time. The term 'qualified home mortgage indebtedness' refers to acquisition indebtedness on the taxpayer's primary residence, meeting specific criteria such as being a traditional mortgage with a term of 15-30 years. The term 'qualified home mortgage indebtedness' refers to a mortgage with a term of 15-30 years, with equal payments made at regular intervals. Married individuals must file joint returns to claim the credit. The credit under subsection (a) is only allowed if an individual files a joint return with their spouse. If the credit is allowed for a joint return, it is treated as allowed to both spouses for that year. The taxpayer is considered to have been allowed the credit for 10 or more preceding years only if both spouses have received the credit. Reporting of excess home mortgage principal payments is also addressed in the code. The Internal Revenue Code has been amended to include reporting requirements for excess home mortgage principal payments. This includes defining the amount of excess payments received during the year and making conforming amendments to related sections of the code. The Internal Revenue Code has been amended to include reporting requirements for excess home mortgage principal payments by inserting a new item after section 36B. The amendments made by section 36C regarding early principal payments on certain home mortgages will apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act.
